none: Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.). School of Music (Contributor)
Northwestern University Video Cassette Collection--Northwestern University Marching Band Highlights
Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.). School of Music
Bernstein, Leonard, 1918-1990. West Side story. America
Bernstein, Leonard, 1918-1990. West Side story. Mambo
Bernstein, Leonard, 1918-1990. West Side story. Tonight

A compilation of Northwestern University Marching Band performances during the 1994-1995 Northwestern Wildcats football season. First are performances from the Northwestern Wildcats versus the Michigan State Spartans at Dyche Stadium and includes "Fanfare," "America the Beautiful," and the National Anthem. Second are performances from another home football game including performances by the Cheer Team to "Celebration," and a Motown medley of "I heard it through the grapevine," "Respect," and "When a man loves a woman," "Stop in the name of love," "My girl," "Dancing in the street," and "A-B-C." Performances from the High School Band Day featuring a medley from Jurassic Park, John Philip Sousa's "The Washington Post" march, "Trumpet voluntary," "Shenandoah," and "Battle Hymn of the Republic." Next are a group of performances including "Got to get you into my life," Chicago's "I just wanna be free," and Paul Simon's "Late in the evening." The next performances features songs from Leonard Bernstein's "West Side Story" including "Mambo," "Tonight," and "America." The final performance includes "Firebird" by Igor Stravinsky. The NU Marching Band was conducted by Stephen G. Peterson and Matthew Ludwig.

The recordings on this web site are provided for use by Northwestern University students, faculty, staff and guests. Further distribution and/or any commercial use of these recordings from this site is strictly prohibited. Please contact specialcollections@northwestern.edu for more information
Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections API
Homepage at Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections

Digitization of this collection was funded by a generous gift from the family of Music professor and bandleader John Phillip Paynter, who began his musical studies at Northwestern, graduating with a Bachelor of Music degree in 1950 and a Master's in Theory and Composition in 1951. Upon graduation, Paynter joined NU's faculty as the Director of the Marching Band. During his career at Northwestern, Paynter taught classes in band music, conducting, and arranging.
